Keywords: Central City , Future , Justice League , Justice Society , Past , Police , Scientist , Speedster , Teen Titans , Young Justice
Real Name: Barry Allen
Special Powers
TEAM FLASH: During force construction, you may only include up to three WW80 #053 The Flash on your starting force. Each WW80 #053 The Flash added after the first only costs 20 points to add. At the beginning of the game, you must choose a distinct starting line for each WW80 #053 The Flash on your starting force and they all have a 30 point value for all effects this game (including scoring).
BACK IN A FLASH!: [Improved Movement: Characters], Charge. Once per turn, when The Flash uses it, after resolutions he may use Charge as FREE.
SPEED YOU IN AND OUT OF DANGER: Telekinesis. When The Flash uses it to place a friendly character, after resolutions you may place that character within 2 squares and line of fire of their current square.
INFRARED GOGGLES LET ME FIND THE BAD GUYS: Enhancement, Outwit. // FREE: [Improved Targeting: Elevated, Hindering, Characters]. Choose an opposing character within 6 squares and line of fire. This turn, lines of fire drawn to that character can't be hindered.

January 23, 2022
Dortmuner
[QUOTE=SuperClixer;12179017]You can think what you want. Just because the part of the power that references two figures reads the way it does, it is the fact the Dr. Fate power has additional wording that defines how many you can use in total, which is absent from the Flash's power, thus you cannot treat it the same. Your better off talking to a Judge or emailing Wizkids. I am only using two.[/QUOTE] You are obviously free to play by whatever house rules you and your play group want, but the rules on the card allow for up to three. The second part of Fate's trait is not what allows him to have more than 2. It is an additional power that does not refer to the first part. That is why it is separated by the two slash lines. And it demonstrates that the rule as written on Fate's card and The Flash's card allows for more than two because the second, separate power accepts it as given. [QUOTE]DUPLICATES OF MYSELF FROM THROUGHOUT TIME AND SPACE: During force construction, you may only add Dr. Fate at 10 points if you also have a Dr. Fate starting at 65 points on your starting force. // For all characters with this trait, if you have 2-4 characters named Dr. Fate on your force, Action Total +1; if you have 5+ such characters, Action Total +2.[/QUOTE] It does not say "You are able to have 2-4 characters named Dr. Fate", it says "if you do". Whether you can or not was established by the first line that is identical to The Flash's card. Again, you can play it any way you want in your own games, but the trait definitively allows for 3.
January 23, 2022
SuperClixer
You can think what you want. Just because the part of the power that references the two figures, reads the way it does, does not mean anything. it is the fact that the Dr. Fate power has additional wording beyond that part, that defines how many you can use in total, which is absent from the Flash's power, thus you cannot treat it the same. Your better off talking to a Judge or emailing Wizkids. I am only using two.
January 23, 2022
Dortmuner
[QUOTE=SuperClixer;12178941]Simple logic, tells me if Wizkid's had intended for you to apply another figures trait that is worded differently to other similar but not same traits, they would of made it a Rule. You cannot use a different figures trait to apply to another figure's trait that is worded differently. I do not believe any Judge would allow you to do that. This Flash figure's Trait makes no reference to more than just the only one add of 20 pts, and the one on the starting force of 30 pts. If they intended for you to use more, than that, they would of worded it like the JLU Dr. Fate.[/QUOTE] The wording for the two powers are almost identical for the part of the power that defines using multiples at lower point value. [QUOTE]During force construction, you may only add Dr. Fate at 10 points if you also have a Dr. Fate starting at 65 points on your starting force. [/QUOTE] [QUOTE]During force construction, you may only add WW80 #053 The Flash at 20 points if you also have a The Flash starting at 30 points on your starting force.[/QUOTE] Literally the only difference in the wording is referencing the figure and its point cost. That's the exact part of the power you quoted on the Flash to explain why you thought it referenced one full point character and one lower point version: [QUOTE]IMO, the phrase "you may only add Flash at 20 pts, if you have a Flash at 30 points on your starting force", is referencing a total of two figures. No where does it say, more than one, or three. The use of the word "only" in "you may only add" is to indicate you can only add one at 20 pts, beyond the one on your starting force. The definition of "a" is referring to someone or something for the first time. The use of the word "a" in. "if you have a Flash at 30 pts, is to indicate you can only have one Flash on your starting force at 30 pts, not two.[/QUOTE} You can plug in Dr. Fate's power word for word above using the sane terminology and WizKids obviously wasn't saying You could only use one 65 point Fate and one 10 point one. The added text afterwards does not affect that base power. In the case of Dr. Fate, they end that part of the power there and add a separate clause (separated by double forward slashes) that define an additional element affecting action total. In the case of The Flash, it's an added clause with a condition that limits it to distinct starting lines, of which there are three. There's nothing in the base power to suggest it limits The Flash to two while Fate can have as many as the point total allows. Only the added clause on The Flash changes it to a maximum of three since there are only three distinct starting lines. You can clearly have three Flashes on a team. The card as written says so and the consistency in wording between sets confirms it.
January 23, 2022
SuperClixer
Simple logic, tells me if Wizkid's had intended for you to apply another figures trait that is worded differently to other similar but not same traits, they would of made it a Rule. You cannot use a different figures trait to apply to another figure's trait that is worded differently. I do not believe any Judge would allow you to do that. This Flash figure's Trait makes no reference to more than just the only one add of 20 pts, and the one on the starting force of 30 pts. If they intended for you to use more, than that, they would of worded it like the JLU Dr. Fate.

Dortmuner
[QUOTE=SuperClixer;12178905]This is my take. There is nothing that says Wizkids would only use the word "both", when they meant you can only have two figures. The word "all" means more than one, and does not necessarily mean more than two. IMO, the phrase "you may only add Flash at 20 pts, if you have a Flash at 30 points on your starting force", is referencing a total of two figures. No where does it say, more than one, or three. The use of the word "only" in "you may only add" is to indicate you can only add one at 20 pts, beyond the one on your starting force. The definition of "a" is referring to someone or something for the first time. The use of the word "a" in. "if you have a Flash at 30 pts, is to indicate you can only have one Flash on your starting force at 30 pts, not two. Maybe a Wizkids employee who is a Member can chime in.[/QUOTE] Compare the reading with the reading of JLU 004 Dr. Fate. [QUOTE]DUPLICATES OF MYSELF FROM THROUGHOUT TIME AND SPACE: During force construction, you may only add Dr. Fate at 10 points if you also have a Dr. Fate starting at 65 points on your starting force. // For all characters with this trait, if you have 2-4 characters named Dr. Fate on your force, Action Total +1; if you have 5+ such characters, Action Total +2.[/QUOTE] Simple consistency demonstrates that your reading is incorrect and WizKids does not limit the number of clix with the "you may only add" phrase since Dr. Fate can have more than two copies at 10 points. The only thing that limits it to three Flashes is the requirement that they each have a distinct starting line.

SuperClixer
This is my take. There is nothing that says Wizkids would only use the word "both", when they meant you can only have two figures. The word "all" means more than one, and does not necessarily mean more than two. IMO, the phrase "you may only add Flash at 20 pts, if you have a Flash at 30 points on your starting force", is referencing a total of two figures. No where does it say, more than one, or three. The use of the word "only" in "you may only add" is to indicate you can only add one at 20 pts, beyond the one on your starting force. The definition of "a" is referring to someone or something for the first time. The use of the word "a" in. "if you have a Flash at 30 pts, is to indicate you can only have one Flash on your starting force at 30 pts, not two. Maybe a Wizkids employee who is a Member can chime in.

Dortmuner
[QUOTE=SuperClixer;12178591]I do not think you can play 3 of his, as the one Member alluded to. From reading his Trait, it appears you can only play 2 of him at a time. (one at the 30 pt line and one at the 20 pt line). Am I correct?[/QUOTE] You can play 3 but no more than 3. [QUOTE]Special Team Flash: During force construction, you may only add WW80 #053 The Flash at 20 points if you also have a The Flash starting at 30 points on your starting force. If you do, at the beginning of the game, you must choose a distinct starting line for each one and they all have a 30 point value for all effects this game (including scoring).[/QUOTE] You'll notice the word "all" instead of the word "both". It's designed to be a team of Flashes up to three.

deathtrooper744
It works almost the same as the Joker, Loki, Dr. Fate, Ultrons etc. One is 30 points, and every other Flash is 20 points during force construction. Every one you pay for gets to choose their starting line, but they all are 30 points once the game begins. Yes, you are meant to play multiple of him. I sincerly doubt though that there will be a way to get multiples of him cost effectively though considering the 20-50 dollar price range of the modern super rares.
